I'm not sure if I mentioned this already but SharpNEAT always 
redetermines the allocation of genomes to species whenever the 
compatability threshold changes. This way the speciation reacts to 
changes in th threshold immediately rather than having the effect 
delayed by having to wait for genomes to die.

I also now redetermine speciation if the populations's average 
complexity has changed by some fixed proportion (2% I think) since the 
last time it was done. Doing this prevent the threshold getting out of 
step with the actual population, which can cause a large jumps in the 
number of species when the speciation routine was next run. It's perhaps 
not as efficient or elegant as Ian's scheme but I don't think the CPU 
overhead is too bad with the typical population sizes and complexities 
we currently deal with.

Colin.
